PRACTICING GROUPS WITHIN NAEB• THE TELEVISION STATION OPERATORS PERHAPS
SET THE PACE BY MAKING SEVERAL STATEMENTS TO THE EFFECT THAT THEY FELT
THEY WERE NOT AS WELL REPRESENTED AS THEY SHOULD BE WITHIN THE FRAMEWORK
OF NAEB. It didn’t take very long for the other groups to get into the
ACT AND THE RADIO STATION PEOPLE SOON LET THEIR DESIRES BE KNOWN, FOLLOWED
BY THE INSTRUCTIONAL TELEVISION PEOPLE AND THE . IND I V 1 DUAL MEMBERS AND OTHERS.
AS YOU WILL NOTE IF YOU LOOKED AT THE LATEST PROGRAM, AMPLE TIME WAS
MADE AVAILABLE FOR REGIONAL MEETINGS AS WELL AS FOR MEETINGS OF THE
INTEREST GROUPS. COMMENTS FROM MANY PEOPLE WAS TO THE EFFECT THAT THIS
WAS THE BEST PART OF THE CONVENTION AND THAT CERTAINLY MORE EFFORT SHOULD
BE PUT IN THIS AREA AT FUTURE MEETINGS. THE BOARD DID TAKE NOTICE OF
THIS REQUEST AND HAS GIVEN INSTRUCTIONS TO THE MlLWAKEE PLANNING GROUP
TO WORK DILLIGENTLY TOWARD ACCOMPLISHING IT.
The Board at its meetings had other considerations, such as proposals
FROM A SUBCOMMITTEE SUGGESTING THE CREATION OF NINE REGIONS RATHER THAN
THE PRESENT SIX. THERE WERE ALSO PROPOSALS TO CREATE SEVEN REGIONS AND
TO CHANGE IN A VARIETY OF WAYS THE COMPOSITION OF THE BOARD TO ALLOW FOR
A MORE EQUITABLE REPRESENTATION ON THE PART OF ALL CLASSES OF MEMBERSHIP.
There was considerable discussion of the NAEB as an umbrella group com¬
pared (in the better ways) to the N.E.A. and at least one proposal was
PRESENTED TO THE BOARD AT ITS THURSDAY MORNING SESSION CALLING FOR THE
ORGANIZATION OF SUBGROUPS, COUNCILS, INTEREST AREAS, ETC., WITH POWERS
TO DESIGN AND PROMOTE A PROGRAM OF ACTIVITIES FOR THAT PARTICULAR GROUP
AND DO A NUMBER OF OTHER THINGS, ALL UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE NAEB
Board. All of these proposals were referred back to the Executive
